meanings.def: a small flat piece of metal used as money
examples: They flipped a coin to see who should go first.
You might as well toss a coin to decide.
A coin toss has decided the lucky winner.
The first English gold coin was struck in 1255.
The last silver coins were minted in 1964.
Very few old 5p coins are still in circulation.
What is the probability of the coin landing heads?

meanings.def: the aspect of a situation that is the opposite of or contrasts with the one you have been talking about
used to talk about two ways of looking at the same situation

idioms.idiom: the other side of the coin
idioms.def: the aspect of a situation that is the opposite of or contrasts with the one you have been talking about

idioms.idiom: two sides of the same coin
idioms.def: used to talk about two ways of looking at the same situation

meanings.def: to invent a new word or phrase that other people then begin to use
examples: The term ‘cardboard city’ was coined to describe communities of homeless people living in cardboard boxes.
He was the first to coin the motto ‘Make Love, Not War’.

meanings.def: to make coins out of metal
to earn a lot of money quickly or easily
used to introduce a well-known expression that you have changed slightly in order to be funny
examples: Tasting is believing, to coin a phrase! (= the usual phrase is ‘seeing is believing’).

meanings.def: used to show that you are aware that you are using an expression that is not new
examples: Oh well, no news is good news, to coin a phrase.
